setwd(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>~/Study/UBC/PracticalMachineLearning<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
load(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>project.Rdata<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>

<h3><a id="user-content-load-data" class="anchor" href="#load-data" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Load data</h3>

<ul>
<li>Load data.<br></li>
<li>Remove near zero covariates and those with more than 80% missing values since these variables will not provide much power for prediction.<br></li>
<li>Calculate correlations between each remaining feature to the response, <code>classe</code>. Use <code>spearman</code> rank based correlation because <code>classe</code> is a factor.<br></li>
<li>Plot the two features that have highest correlation with <code>classe</code> and color with <code>classe</code> to see if we can separate response based on these features.<br></li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c"># load data</span>
<span class="pl-smi">training</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>./data/pml-training.csv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">row.names</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">testing</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>./data/pml-testing.csv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">row.names</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>)
<span class="pl-c"># remove near zero covariates</span>
<span class="pl-smi">nsv</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> nearZeroVar(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>, <span class="pl-v">saveMetrics</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">T</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">training</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, <span class="pl-k">!</span><span class="pl-smi">nsv</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">nzv</span>]
<span class="pl-c"># remove variables with more than 80% missing values</span>
<span class="pl-smi">nav</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(colnames(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>), <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-k">if</span>(sum(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, <span class="pl-smi">x</span>])) <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.8</span><span class="pl-k">*</span>nrow(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>)){<span class="pl-k">return</span>(<span class="pl-c1">T</span>)}<span class="pl-k">else</span>{<span class="pl-k">return</span>(<span class="pl-c1">F</span>)})
<span class="pl-smi">training</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, <span class="pl-k">!</span><span class="pl-smi">nav</span>]
<span class="pl-c"># calculate correlations</span>
<span class="pl-smi">cor</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> abs(sapply(colnames(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, <span class="pl-k">-</span>ncol(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>)]), <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) cor(as.numeric(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, <span class="pl-smi">x</span>]), as.numeric(<span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>), <span class="pl-v">method</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>spearman<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c"># plot predictors </span>
summary(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>)
plot(<span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, names(which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>))], <span class="pl-smi">training</span>[, names(which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>[<span class="pl-k">-</span>which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>)]))], <span class="pl-v">col</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-v">pch</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">19</span>, <span class="pl-v">cex</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0.1</span>, <span class="pl-v">xlab</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> names(which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>)), <span class="pl-v">ylab</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> names(which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>[<span class="pl-k">-</span>which.max(<span class="pl-smi">cor</span>)])))</pre></div>

<p>The training set has <strong><code>r nrow(training)</code></strong> samples and <strong><code>r ncol(training) - 1</code></strong> potential predictors after filtering.          </p>

<p>There doesn't seem to be any strong predictors that correlates with <code>classe</code> well, so linear regression model is probably not suitable in this case. Boosting and random forests algorithms may generate more robust predictions for our data.         </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-boosting-model" class="anchor" href="#boosting-model" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Boosting model</h3>

<ul>
<li>Fit model with boosting algorithm and 10-fold cross validation to predict <code>classe</code> with all other predictors.<br></li>
<li>Plot accuracy of this model on the scale <code>[0.9, 1]</code>.<br></li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>set.seed(<span class="pl-c1">123</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">boostFit</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> train(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-v">method</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>gbm<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span>, <span class="pl-v">verbose</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">F</span>, <span class="pl-v">trControl</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> trainControl(<span class="pl-v">method</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>cv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">number</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">boostFit</span>
plot(<span class="pl-smi">boostFit</span>, <span class="pl-v">ylim</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">0.9</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>))</pre></div>

<p>The boosting algorithm generated a good model with <strong>accuracy = 0.997</strong>. </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-random-forests-model" class="anchor" href="#random-forests-model" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Random forests model</h3>

<ul>
<li>Fit model with random forests algorithm and 10-fold cross validation to predict <code>classe</code> with all other predictors.<br></li>
<li>Plot accuracy of the model on the <strong>same scale</strong> as boosting model.<br></li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre>set.seed(<span class="pl-c1">123</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> train(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> ., <span class="pl-v">method</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>rf<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">training</span>, <span class="pl-v">importance</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">T</span>, <span class="pl-v">trControl</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> trainControl(<span class="pl-v">method</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>cv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-v">number</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span>
plot(<span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span>, <span class="pl-v">ylim</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> c(<span class="pl-c1">0.9</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">imp</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> varImp(<span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span>)<span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">importance</span>
<span class="pl-smi">imp</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">max</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> apply(<span class="pl-smi">imp</span>, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-smi">max</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">imp</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">imp</span>[order(<span class="pl-smi">imp</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">max</span>, <span class="pl-v">decreasing</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">T</span>), ]</pre></div>

<p>The random forests algorithm generated a very accurate model with <strong>accuracy close to 1</strong>. Compared to boosting model, this model generally has better performance in terms of accuracy as we see from the plots.                     </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-final-model-and-prediction" class="anchor" href="#final-model-and-prediction" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Final model and prediction</h3>

<ul>
<li>Comparing model accuracy of the two models generated, random forests and boosting, random forests model has overall better accuracy. So, I'll use this model for prediction.<br></li>
<li>The final random forests model contains 500 trees with 40 variables tried at each split. The five most important predictors in this model are <code>r rownames(imp)[1:5]</code>.<br></li>
<li>Estimated <strong>out of sample error rate</strong> for the random forests model is <strong>0.04%</strong> as reported by the final model.<br></li>
<li>Predict the test set and output results for automatic grader.<br></li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c"># final model</span>
<span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">finalModel</span>
<span class="pl-c"># prediction</span>
(<span class="pl-smi">prediction</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> as.character(predict(<span class="pl-smi">rfFit</span>, <span class="pl-smi">testing</span>)))</pre></div>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-r"><pre><span class="pl-c"># write prediction files</span>
<span class="pl-v">pml_write_files</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>){
  <span class="pl-v">n</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> length(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)
  <span class="pl-k">for</span>(<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>){
    <span class="pl-v">filename</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> paste0(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>./prediction/problem_id_<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">i</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>.txt<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
    write.table(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>[<span class="pl-smi">i</span>], <span class="pl-v">file</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">filename</span>, <span class="pl-v">quote</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>, <span class="pl-v">row.names</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>, <span class="pl-v">col.names</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
  }
}
pml_write_files(<span class="pl-smi">prediction</span>)</pre></div>
</article>
